newsitem.title: USA: Cotter, ServiStar deal not seen as hardware threat.
newsitem.headline: Cotter, ServiStar deal not seen as hardware threat.

text.p: The merger between Cotter & Co and ServiStar Coast to Coast Corp is not expected to cause competitors like Sears, Roebuck and Co or Home Depot to shift business strategies, industry analysts said.
"The smaller hardware stores have been struggling to compete with the larger stores for market share," said Christopher Vroom, an analyst at Alex. Brown & Sons.
"I see this as a merger out of weakness, not out of strength," he said, "and I don't see the new company as a stronger threat to Home Depot or Lowes (Cos.) (than before)."

Combining the nation's number-one and number-three hardware store co-operatives will create a network of more than 10,500 independent stores with total annual sales of $4.5 billion. Both Cotter, which sells products to True Value Hardware stores, and ServiStar expect the deal to increase their competitiveness and improve operating efficiencies as they leap-frog over number-two Ace Hardware Corp.

"About 150 of the 382 employees affected as a result of the merger will be offered the chance to move to Chicago," said Paul Pentz, ServiStar's chief executive, and the president and chief operating officer of the new TruServ Corp.
Pentz said TruServ will have a net loss of 314 jobs once 68 jobs move to E. Butler, Pa., where ServiStar is located.
TruServ, made up of the True Value, ServiStar and Coast to Coast chains, is not expected to suddenly become a threat to larger players like Home Depot or Lowes, said analysts.
"I don't think the merger will have much of an effect on Home Depot's strategies or operations," said Skip Helm, an analyst at William Blair & Co.
Alex. Brown analyst Vroom agreed. "Together, Home Depot and Lowes control 17 percent of the (hardware) market nationwide," he said.
"We're projecting that to be 50 percent by 2000, and this merger has not changed that view," Vroom said.
The major do-it-yourself hardware superstores did not appear fazed at the prospect of a massive network of independent operations, since they compete for different customers.

"I don't see any change in our strategy (because of the True Value/ServiStar merger)," confirmed a Lowes spokesman. "Competition exists with the smaller hardware stores, but we try to differentiate ourselves as more of a destination warehouse, where you can buy materials for an entire project."
As Joseph Ronning, an analyst at Brown Brothers Harriman & Co, points out, "Stores like Sears look for the 'fix-it' customer, while the Home Depots look for the 'build-it' customer."
Officials at Home Depot could not be reached for comment.

In a prepared statement, Ace Hardware said the merger was neither a surprise, nor a threat to Ace's "continued growth in the industry." Ace Hardware is a co-operative of more than 5,000 independent hardware stores in 50 states and 56 nations.
